review_blob:
500 ml bottle from the LCBO.
Appearance: Pours a slightly hazy copper colour with lots of white head. Average retention and lacing.
Aroma:
Barely a hint of malt but nothing else. Almost no scent to this beer.
Flavours:
Caramel malt, some oats and a hint of rye.
Mouthfeel: Average viscosity and carbonation.
Overall: Disappointed overall with this one. Ive had other Forked River beers and was impressed. This one didnt seem to have much going on.
beer_name: Forked River Riptide Rye Pale Ale

review_blob:
355 ml bottle from a six pack bought at the LCBO.
Appearance: Pours a gleaming copper colour with fingers of pillowy white head. Average retention and tons of lacing.
Aroma:
Pine, peach and citrus.
Flavours:
Pine, peach and citrus.
Mouthfeel: Thick and coating.
Overall: Gorgeous peach aroma and flavour in this one. One of the best IPAs Ive had in a long while.

500 ml bottle from an picerie in Qubec City.
Appearance: Pours a
clear amber color with just a bit of loose white head. Short retention and sight lacing.
Aroma:
Malt bit of hops
Flavours:
Malt, caramel, cereal.
Mouthfeel:
Average viscosity, a bit flat and one dimensional.
Overall: I like the malt but this one just doesnt pull it off. It comes across as one dimensional and not that interesting.

650 ml bottle from the LCBO.
Appearance: Pours a
murky yellow with just over a finger of crisp white head. Very short retention and almost no lacing.
Aroma:
Salt crackers, earthy mushrooms, dried grass, licorice.
Flavours:
Grains, yeast, salt, dry grass, hint of lemon, some interesting sour notes. 
Mouthfeel:
Thinner with lots of carbonation - almost effervescent. 
Overall: While Im not usually a big fan of Saisons, this one was enjoyable with some interesting sour notes on the finish. The salt on the aroma and amongst the flavours was what stood out most.

500 ml bottle from a small dpanneur in Alymer.
Appearance: Pours jet black with barely a finger of tan head. Short retention and no lacing.
Aroma:
Burnt chocolate, coffee, molasses.
Flavours:
Roasted malt, smoke, coco, dark chocolate, black coffee.
Mouthfeel:
A bit thinner but with a nice lingering finish.
Overall: A pretty good Baltic Porter with all of the roasted malt, dark chocolate and coffee flavour you would expect. While this is not one of the more complex Porters Ive had in this style, it is a very enjoyable beer.

750 ml bottle from a dpanneur in Alymer.
Appearance: Pours a
cloudy light copper color with lots of creamy white head which makes a crackling sound as it disipates. Medium retention and sight lacing.
Aroma:
Yeast, malt, bread.
Flavours:
Rye, yeast, malt, cereal, very slight smokiness.
Mouthfeel:
Average viscosity with a bit higher carbonation which is typical with Unibroue beers.
Overall: Decent beer and I can pick up a bit of the smokiness in the flavour but not in the aroma. It has a bit more complexity than I expected and is quite easy to drink.

Appearance: Pours a cloudy yellow with a fair bit of thick white head. Short retention and quite a bit of lace.
Aroma:
Floral notes, yeast, cloves.
Flavours:
Yeast, lemon, flowers, cloves.
Mouthfeel: Lots of carbonation and an effervescent feel.
Overall: Nice beer with floral notes, some interesting flavours I cant quite pick out and some nice nuances. This seems to be a lot more Belgian Ale than IPA, at least compared to the IPAs Im used to. Im getting lots of yeast and lemon but none of the typical hops or grapefruit notes.
beer_name: Les Brasseurs du Temps Carpe Diem

review_blob:
500 ml bottle from an picerie in Qubec City.
Appearance: Pours a
clear gorgeous copper colour with a bit of white head. Short retention and minimal lacing.
Aroma:
Citrus and pine.
Flavours:
Pure citrus, grapefruit orange, lime, lemon etc.
Mouthfeel:
Crisp with a nice lingering finish.
Overall: Love this IPA. So much rich citrus flavour and some sweetness coming through.

600 ml bottle from the LCBO.
Appearance: Pours an opaque black with a couple fingers of tan head. Short retention with heavy lacing.
Aroma:
Malt, wheat, bit of pine.
Flavours:
Malt, biscuit, grain, hint of hops.
Mouthfeel:
Average viscosity with a fair bit of carbonation.
Overall: This one started off very malty with almost no hop presence and gradually changed to almost all hops with a very bitter finish. I didnt know that beaus could make beer with such character.

500 ml bottle from an picerie in Qubec City.
Appearance: Pours a
dark black with a whisper of tan head. Virtually no lacing.
Aroma:
Popcorn, dark chocolate, coffee.
Flavours:
Black coffee, dark chocolate, roasted malt, bit of charcoal.
Mouthfeel:
Thick and coating.
Overall: Nice stout and the popcorn aroma was unusual. The layers of aromas and flavours put this stout above the average ones Ive had but not quite into the upper tier.

473 ml can from the SAQ.
Appearance: Pours a deep clear copper colour with a couple fingers of white head. Average retention and lots of lacing.
Aroma:
Malt, tobacco, cereal.
Flavours:
Malt, cereal, hint of tobacco.
Mouthfeel: Smooth and flat.
Overall: This would make a decent Brown ale with all of the malt but I didnt get any of the usual IPA pine or citrus aromas and flavors.
beer_name: Farnham Ale & Lager 64 - India Pale Ale

review_blob:
750 ml bottle from the LCBO.
Appearance: Pours a dense brown with a finger of off white head. Average retention and lacing.
Aroma:
Maple with a bit of cherry liqueur.
Flavours:
Maple, cherry liqueur with some moca and chocolate notes.
Mouthfeel: Thin with light carbonation.
Overall: A great maple Porter and likely one of the best Ive had. The subtle nuances of cherry liqueur adds a nice touch.

750 ml bottle from a small dpanneur in Gatineau.
Appearance: Pours jet black with no light coming through. Has a few fingers of tan head with good retention.
Aroma:
Bourbon, coffee, licorice.
Flavours:
Bourbon, moca, molasses, some tobacco and vanilla.
Mouthfeel:
Thicker coating mouthfeel. Average carbonation.
Overall: Nice Baltic Porter with interesting oak characteristics like tobacco and vanilla coming through.
beer_name: Les Trois Mousquetaires G.C. Porter Baltique d.Spc. (Bourbon & Brandy)

review_blob:
750 ml bottle from a dpanneur in Gatineau.
Aroma:
Interesting yeasts, leather, allspice, caramel, hint of bourbon, oak.
Flavours:
Caramel, toffee, candy floss, leather, tobacco, bit of bourbon and oak barrels.
Mouthfeel: Average viscosity and higher carbonation.
Overall: Quite complex with lots of aromas and flavours that evolve as the beer is open and warms up. Similar to the Nickel Brook Cuve.
beer_name: Les Brasseurs du Temps Brett de Hull Ft de Pinot Noir

review_blob:
600 ml bottle from the LCBO.
Aroma:
Sweet malt, yeast, caramel
Flavours:
Biscuit, malt, yeast, hints of caramel.
Mouthfeel: Thin with low carbonation.
Overall: Not a bad Scottish Ale. Less sweet than others Ive had but still lots of interesting biscuit and caramel flavour.

500 ml bottle from the SAQ.
Appearance: Pours a clear amber colour with tons of head.
Aroma:
Light malt.
Flavours:
Bitter caramel, grain.
Mouthfeel: Thin with moderate carbonation.
Overall: Its been a long while since I had this and it now seems like another macro beer. Okay malt profile but not something I care to drink again.

341 ml bottle from the SAQ.
Appearance: Pours a
slightly cloudy pale yellow with nearly a finger of white head.
Aroma:
Yeast, lemon and hints of other citrus.
Flavours:
Yeast, lemon, lime.
Mouthfeel:
Average viscosity with effervescent carbonation.
Overall: Decent Wheat Beer with the typical yeasty, citrusy characteristics.
beer_name: Dieu du Ciel Blanche du Paradis
Dieu du Ciel Corne du Diable

beer_brewer_name: Microbrasserie Le Castor - Le Castor Brewing Co.
review_blob:
650 ml bottle from a small dpanneur in Gatineau. 
Appearance: Pours a
bronzy amber colour with a finger of white head. Short retention and little lacing.
Aroma:
Hops, yeast.
Flavours:
Hops, pine, yeast, lemon, bit of grapefruit.
Mouthfeel:
Average viscosity and carbonation. 
Overall: Nice IPA with a surprising amount of hops and pine flavour for a session beer. Ill definately go back and get more.

750 ml bottle from a small dpanneur in Gatineau.
Appearance: Pours a hazy orange with a couple fingers of white head. Retention is very short and lacing is non-existent.
Aroma: Belgian yeast, hazel nuts, fruity notes.
Flavours: Belgian yeast, flour, straw, nuts, dried fruit.
Mouthfeel: Thinner with average carbonation.
Overall: Decent Belgian Ale but not something I would rush out to buy again.

453 ml can from the LCBO.
Appearance: Pours opaque black with no light coming through even when held up to the light. Slight tan head.
Aroma: Burnt malt, caramel.
Flavours: Burnt malt.
Mouthfeel: Average viscosity and carbonation.
Overall: Good but not a lot of flavours.
beer_name: Sawdust City Long, Dark Voyage to Uranus

review_blob:
650 ml bottle from the LCBO.
Aroma: Gingerbread, malted milk.
Flavours: Ginger, gingerbread, malted milk, milk chocolate.
Mouthfeel: Rich and thick but lower carbonation.
Overall: Really nice Stout with gingerbread aromas and flavours that are strong but not overpowering.
beer_name: Central City Red Racer Gingerhead Gingerbread Stout

beer_brewer_name: Microbrasserie Le Castor - Le Castor Brewing Co.
review_blob:
600 ml bottle from a small dpanneur in Gatineau.
Aroma: Dark malt, black coffee
Flavours: Black coffee, toasted malt
Mouthfeel: Average viscocity and carbination. 
Overall: Decent Black IPA with the coffee and dark malt flavours I love.

500 ml bottle from the LCBO.
Appearance: Pours an opaque black with just a bit of tan head. 
Aroma:
Fresh ground coffee, dark chocolate.
Flavours:
Fresh coffee, dark chocolate.
Mouthfeel:
Thicker with average carbonation. 
Overall: Wow, what a really great Porter! Havent had one this good in quite a while. Boat loads of coffee and chocolate come out really strong and fresh.

650 ml bottle from the LCBO.
Appearance: Pours a
clear dark amber brown with next to no head. That said, there is a bit of lacing left behind. 
Aroma:
Malt, custard.
Flavours:
Malt, caramel, toffee, hint of grapefruit with a very slight bitterness on the finish. 
Mouthfeel:
Average viscosity with lower carbonation. 
Overall: A nice ale with malty flavours coming through but it also has a hint of citrus with some grapefruit coming out. I found this one to be fairly easy drinking. This bottle was just slightly past its best by date so I suspect the hops might have been more intense if it were fresher.

beer_brewer_name: Microbrasserie Le Castor - Le Castor Brewing Co.
review_blob:
Appearance: Pours a hazy yellow with two hands of white that recedes after an hour. The bottle gushed beer all over the counter when opened, even though it was handled carefully, indicating it is over carbonated.
Aroma:
Lemon, barnyard.
Flavours:
Hay, lemon, rubber.
Mouthfeel: Thin with too much carbonation 
Overall: An alright Saison but by far this is Le Castors weakest offering. Some interesting aromas but not much more than that.
beer_name: Le Castor Farmhouse Houblon Batches 4 to X

review_blob:
500 ml can from the LCBO.
Appearance: Pours a hazy yellow with more head than Ive seen on a beer. Retention is quite long. Moderate lacing.
Aroma:
Pine, yeast.
Flavours:
Pine, grapefruit, mango, apricot.
Mouthfeel: Average viscosity. Average carbonation which is surprising given the mountains of head this thing produced.
Overall: What an interesting mixture of the typical bitter hop characteristics with the sweet tropical fruit as well.

750 ml bottle from a small dpanneur over in Gatineau.
Appearance: Pours a deep hazy brown with a couple solid fingers of tan head. Good retention and lacing.
Aroma:
Caramel malt, toffee, peat, tar.
Flavours:
Burnt malt, black coffee, nuts, oak, hint of vanilla and an earthy bitter finish.
Mouthfeel: Average viscosity and carbonation.
Overall: A nice Scotch Ale but I would have preferred it a bit more on the sweet, malty caramel side rather than being more dark malt and bitterness.
beer_name: Les Brasseurs du Temps La Corne et la Muse

beer_brewer_name: Microbrasserie Le Castor - Le Castor Brewing Co.
review_blob:
660 ml bottle from a small dpanneur in Gatineau.
Appearance: Pours jet black with mounds of tan head. Decent retention and a fair bit of lacing.
Aroma:
Strong pine and earthy hops with a hint of tea.
Flavours:
Pine, grapefruit, other citrus notes with hints of coffee and roasted malt on the finish.
Mouthfeel: Thicker mouthfeel with lots of carbonation.
Overall: This is quite a good Black IPA and reminds me of Nickel Brooks Malevolent Black IPA. Lots of pine and grapefruit up front but this doesnt overpower the nice coffee/dark malt on the finish.
beer_name: Le Castor / Pit Caribou 30 Cents IPA Noire

review_blob:
750 ml bottle from a little dpanner in Gatineau.
Appearance: Pours jet black with mountains of tan head. Exceedingly long retention and massive amounts of lacing.
Aroma:
Coffee, roasted malt, charcoal, magic marker.
Flavours:
Coffee, roasted malt, charcoal, burnt coffee grounds, cola and some vanilla.
Mouthfeel: Thinner mouthfeel with average carbonation.
Overall: A decent stout but thinner than many others Ive had. Lots of flavours coming out but it just didnt wow me. Perhaps a bit too bitter.
beer_name: Les Brasseurs du Temps Obscur Dsir

review_blob:
600 ml bottle from the Beaus Octoberfest pack.
Appearance: Pours a clear yellow with lots of white head. Retention is good and there is a ton of lacing left behind.
Aroma:
Grapefruit and other citrus with some biscuit.
Flavours:
Grapefruit, mango, orange, biscuit. 
Mouthfeel: Average viscosity and carbonation.
Overall: I found this to be a different take on a Kolsh beer in that it had a lot of citrus and sweet fruit which I wasnt expecting. Overall, I was quite impressed with this one.

750 ml bottle from the LCBO.
Appearance: Pours a
clear straw yellow with a couple fingers of white head that fade rapidly leaving little lace. 
Aroma:
Hops, grapefruit, bit of bread
Flavours:
Grapefruit, lemon, lime and other citrus. Sweeter flavours like apple and peach come out after the beer is open for a bit. 
Mouthfeel:
 Thinner with average carbonation. 
Overall: An interesting blend of citrus that turns towards the sweet side after the beer is open a while. I found it a little on the thin side but the interesting flavours made this one an enjoyable beer.
beer_name: Nickel Brook Ontario Wet Hop Pale Ale

review_blob: Black coffee, roasted malt, dark chocolate, charcoal and some licorice coming though. Fair bit of complexity to this one.

600 ml bottle from the Octoberfest pack.
Appearance: Pours a
hazy yellow colour with not quite a finger of white head. Average retention and a bit of lacing.
Aroma:
Salt and brine.
Flavours:
Lemon, biscuit, salt.
Mouthfeel:
Thiner with average carbonation. 
Overall: This was quite a nice beer and similar to Beaus Opas Gose. The salt and sour flavours come on strong and work well together.
beer_name: Beaus And Boom Gose The Dynamite

review_blob:
750 ml bottle from a friend.
Appearance: Pours a thick dark brown copper colour with a couple fingers of dense tan head. Short retention and lots of lacing.
Aroma:
Caramel malt, bit of yeast, biscuit.
Flavours:
Malt, caramel, toffee, dates and figs.
Mouthfeel: Thick with lots of carbonation.
Overall: A nice and unusual ESB in that this one is pretty strong and more complex than a typical ESB.
beer_name: Flying Monkeys Coast to Coastless Collaboration

review_blob:
600 ml bottle from Beaus Octoberfest pack.
Appearance: Pours a hazy dark amber colour with a couple fingers of dense white head. with lingering retention.
Aroma:
Malt, bread.
Flavours:
Biscuit, malt, banana, cloves.
Mouthfeel: Average viscosity and carbonation.
Overall: A nice wheat beer with a few interesting nuances.

600 ml bottle from the Oktoberfest pack.
Appearance: Pours a hazy amber colour with a finger of white head.
Aroma:
Flowers, yeast, grass, clover.
Flavours:
Yeast, flowers, hint of banana and ginger.
Mouthfeel: Thinner with lots of carbonation.
Overall: Where is the pumpkin? I get zero pumpkin aroma and none in the flavours. This is an okay Wheat beer but there is no pumpkin.

650 ml bottle from Burlington VT.
Appearance: Pours a
cloudy brown redish colour with just over a finger of tan head. Short retention and considerable lacing.
Aroma:
Malted milk.
Flavours:
Malted milk, sweet bready malts, cereal, toffee, hazel nuts, some dark fruit like dates and figs, hint of orange marmalade on the finish.
Mouthfeel:
Thicker and smooth but with a bit of a bitter sharp finish. 
Overall: The malted milk flavour really comes out strong. Nice secondary flavours of dark fruit and orange marmalade added a nice touch.

650 ml bottle from Burlington VT.
Appearance: Pours jet black with a good finger of tan head. Short retention and minimal lacing. 
Aroma:
Coffee, burnt malt, dill pickles. 
Flavours:
Cappuccino, moca, chocolate, dark roasted malt.
Mouthfeel:
Thicker and coating. Moderate carbonation.
Overall: Really one of the best stouts Ive had. Many different flavours coming together so well.

355 ml bottle from a friend. 
Appearance: Pours a deep dark copper colour with a finger of head and minimal lacing.
Aroma:
Caramel malt, bit of pine.
Flavours:
Caramel malt, some hops, oranges, mango.
Mouthfeel: Average viscosity and carbonation. 
Overall: This one is a different and very good IPA. It leans towards the malt side of things but still has some hops coming through. Although it is 105 IBUs, it didnt seem that bitter to me.

650 ml bottle from the LCBO courtesy of a friend. Nice malt and hops from this one. Crisp bitter finish. The malt in the bottled version is more pronounced than I remember it being on draft. Another really good beer from Great Lakes Brewery.

330 ml bottle from a friend in Boston. 
Appearance: Pours a semi hazy pale orange colour with barely a finger of white head. Short retention and no lacing. 
Aroma:
Grapefruit and other citrus, pine.
Flavours:
Grapefruit, grass, bit of pine.
Mouthfeel: Thicker coating mouthfeel with average carbonation. 
Overall: Nice IPA with the usual citrus and pine flavours.
beer_name: Boulevard Smokestack Series - The Calling IPA

review_blob:
Bottle from a friend in Boston. 
Appearance: Pours a clear pale copper colour with a bit of white head. Short retention and just a bit of lacing.
Aroma:
Grapefruit, bit of orange
Flavours:
Grapefruit, orange, hint of hops. 
Mouthfeel: Average viscosity and carbonation. 
Overall: A very nice pale ale with lots of citrus and a bit of hops.
beer_name: Lagunitas A Little Sumpin Sumpin Ale

review_blob:
355 ml can from a friend. 
Appearance: Pours a clear light copper colour with a finger of loose white head that fades fast leaving barely a trace. 
Aroma:
Biscuit, malt.
Flavours:
Citrus, hops, some biscuit. 
Mouthfeel: Average viscosity and carbonation. 
Overall: With all the malt and biscuit aromas, I wasnt expecting much in the way of citrus or hop flavours but there was lots of citrus coming through. A pretty good IPA overall and a nice balance between malt and hops.
beer_name: 21st Amendment Brew Free or Die IPA

review_blob:
1 pint bottle from Beverage Depot in Burlington Vermont.
Appearance: Pours a
dark black with a finger of light tan head. Short retention, slight lacing.
Aroma:
Dough, hint of coffee.
Flavours:
Coco beans, vanilla, smoke, coffee, moca, raisins and prunes. 
Mouthfeel:
Average viscosity, lingering finish, average carbonation. 
Overall: Nice Porter in which the vanilla and coffee beans really come out. The dark fruits like raisins and prunes come out as it begins to warm.

1 pint bottle from Hunger Mountain Coop in Montpellier Vermont.
Appearance: Pours an opaque black with half a finger of tan head. Short retention, zero lacing.
Aroma:
 Chocolate, must, hint of pine, moca.
Flavours:
Dark malt, root beer, molasses, black coffee, bit of charcoal, caramel notes as it warms. 
Mouthfeel:
Thicker and coating with good carbonation. 
Overall: Really nice Imperial Stout with a number of different aromas and flavours. This one has some subtle nuances and the aromas and flavours become more pronounced as it warms.

330 ml bottle from the LCBO.
Appearance: Pours a
hazy golden yellow with a finger of white head. Retention is short and lacing dense.
Aroma:
Flour, yeast.
Flavours:
Yeast, fresh dough, lemon and sour fruit.
Mouthfeel:
Average viscosity and higher carbonation. Harsh bitter finish.
Overall: Did not really like this and would say it rates among the worst beers Ive had.

500 ml bottle from a dpanneur in Gatineau.
Appearance: Pours jet black with mountains of head and long retention. Moderate lacing.
Aroma:
Charcoal, bourbon, dark malt, molasses, nuts and a bit of a funky barnyard smell.
Flavours:
Bourbon, oak, coals, dark malt, black tea.
Mouthfeel:
Thinner with average carbonation. 
Overall: Enjoyable Porter overall with lots going on. I really liked the complex aromas and that hint of what I can only describe as "funky barnyard" to borrow some wine descriptors. The only thing I wasnt that keen on was it was a bit thinner.

750 ml bottle from BDT.
Appearance: Pours an opaque candy brown colour with a bit of tan head. 
Aroma:
Honey, dark malt.
Flavours:
Honey, brown sugar, toffee, caramel, dark malt, moca, chocolate, molasses, figs.
Mouthfeel: Thick and coating with average carbonation. 
Overall: A luscious Barley Wine with gobs of honey on the aroma and in the flavour. This shifts towards caramel and honey after it had been open a while. Overall, I would say this is a really nice well put together beer with a fair bit of complexity.
beer_name: Les Brasseurs du Temps Mea Magna Culpa

review_blob:
330 ml bottle from the LCBO.
Appearance: Pours a
hazy light brown with over a finger of tan head. Shorter retention and very little lacing.
Aroma:
Biscuit and bready malts.
Flavours:
Belgian yeast, dark malts, prunes, walnuts, brown sugar and hints of milk chocolate. 
Mouthfeel:
Average viscosity and higher carbonation. 
Overall: This is a nice Belgian ale but no where near as enjoyable as the Rochfort 10 in my opinion. Lots going on in the aromas and flavours but I dont get the subtle nuances that I got with Rochfort 10.
